name: Tawny Frogmouth
description: It has a relatively large head, a wide beak with a sharp, downward-curved upper jaw, and large, forward-facing eyes. Its coloration is subtle, in shades of gray and brown.
food_note: Large insects and other invertebrates, small vertebrates
proportions: Body length 14–24 cm; tail 20–22 cm; wingspan 125 cm; weight 300–700 g
attractions: The tawny frogmouth is a nocturnal creature, hunting at dusk and capable of catching insects in flight. It is equipped with a wide beak fringed with fine feathers resembling whiskers. During the day, it uses its perfect camouflage, looking like a dry stump while resting on a tree or shrub. Tawny frogmouths live in permanent pairs, with both parents caring for the young.
breeding: We have kept tawny frogmouths since 1993, when we imported three males and one female from Wuppertal Zoo. One of the males still lives at the zoo and has fathered three successfully raised chicks (the first successful breeding was in 2000).
